title: TSM!!! TSM!!! TSM!!!
body:
"YES WE CAN AND YES WE WILL!"

-2015 LCS NA Spring Split Champions


...on a more serious note:  TSM needs to radically upgrade it's Teamfighting abilities/consistency if it wants to win MSI.  Although they can teamfight; the results are not always reliable and because Asian teams have a hyper-aggressive playstyle, they may be caught off guard more then once.

I must say Dyrus did good this time which was surprising alas.  Indeed he did get to play League of Legends.  GG with Lustboy on support {{champion:85}} .  Not only did C9 ban attempts to target support backfire... it actually gave TSM a composition that worked even better.

Also... why does anyone use {{champion:117}} anymore?  She has been completely a waste of space LCS wise for ages now, and even on the few games her team wins, she has little impact thereof.


All in all:  Outside of first game "sloppiness" which seems to follow TSM around, they did dominate the series thereafter.  If they can work on some things they are still shy on, and make sure to get their teamfighting in order for countering Asian playstyles, they should have a shot at MSI.


That is... if Fnatic doesn't stop them first {{champion:40}} 


Indeed it is so...

I'll admit that Wildturtle did well that series, but I also feel that sneaky wasn't really given the same chance to shine in that series due to the fact that his team was normally behind. So perhaps Wildturtle is the best adc NA, but outside of very even and close games, it's hard to concretely say which of the two is the better adc especially when we consider the number of lane swaps in those four games; Wildturtle never duo laned against sneaky and vice-versa.

Wildturtle got a kill on LemonNation 2v2 top in game 2 if I remember correctly.

I think Sneaky is a great adc and probably better in lane than Wildturtle, but when it comes to teamfights you can see that Wildturtle is on a higher level than Sneaky, the positioning, the fast decision making and also his awareness are unrivaled by any AD carry in NA.

Lag improvements and minor changes are all "small fish".  These are not large scale projects that alter the game in any way.  World of Warcraft; for example, does this all time even now, alas it is but a shell of its former glory.  Riot has "bigger fish to fry" indeed.

Like... is LoL going to be here 20 years from now?  Even you probably would assume it wouldn't last 20 years.  Even 10 years you may agree.  Just because it may be the "highest viewed on Twich" is like saying your King of an Empty Wasteland that has few competition, and minimal interest.  Even if the total viewership (**defined as EU/NA; non Asian regions**) is 1-3million (which is a generious estimate) it is still a fraction of the overall game industry.  Elder Scrolls Online may still have approx. 1 million "users" (log in at least once a month) but yet nobody here is saying how wonderful that game is.  Guild Wars 2 most certainly has somewhere near that according to their own statistics but yet the same.

The point is:  If LoL is ever going to "become something other then a niche' concept" and broaden its appeal to far greater number of players... the current strategy isn't working.  Every once and awhile there are "glimmers of hope" such as with their Original Video ANimations (The New Dawn as example) but without more concrete basis yet nothing.


And lets not forget:  There is a whole section of this forum about people {{item:3070}}  {{item:3070}}  about the wholesale abandonment of the Game's Lore and continuously broken Riot Promises that "something is just right around the corner" (been saying that for years now).

The conclusion is that; if there is not something "right around the corner", this game will forever be limited to a purely "Player vs Player" audience, which currently industry wide as a MOBA, is very limited in appeal.

I don't know what novels you have been reading but Riot is looking to the future, they have clear definitive plans for the future. Just as an example in NA, they are working to strengthen the connection for all games whether east coast or west coast so as to give all areas of NA the same level gameplay (ping, packet speed and quality).

Constant balance changes, texture updates and item development grounds the game in a constantly evolving playstyle that attempts to improve gameplay and the "fun" of the game.

I understand that you have a clear idea of what Riot should do to make the game have its staying power, but that isn't the only route to be sure. I would be surprised if the game didn't have another 5 years in it at least, though most of the appeal will be generated by various leagues of competitive play as it is right now.

Competitive League expands upon the Word of Mouth logic and brings in collectively more and more fans.  Content that Riot creates for lore, or events bring in even more interest in the game. Content creators on youtube, ongamers, surrender@20, insight on esports, ogn plus and countless others enforce and feed our need for information, gameplay and discussion.

League of legends is constantly the top game streamed on twitch, rarely is it budged from that pedestal. Personalities drive games to be watched, discussed and trolled. Professional hone their skills while everyone watches. Riot Employees steam for the sheer fun they have playing the game that is their career.

I have to disagree with you in ever facet you have pointed out, league is here to stay and while I may note know Riots every last detail for the future, they are going to keep this game going for a while and they are going to make it kick ass.

> [{quoted}](name=Vixanys,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=gmYrqzXW,comment-id=00010001000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000004,timestamp=2015-04-30T05:54:18.036+0000)

> 
> This is the biggest "marketing" point that League has. 


Yes... however this own shall be Riot's downfall:  The same "word of mouth" also can be used against LoL (as it is now).  Lag (for EU), AFKers/Trolls, Bronze Drama, Skill Differential (lack of a proper "on-boarding process" for new players), Champion Balance, Meta Issues (the jungle for example)... all of these and more bring the game back around.

Indeed "popular opinion" did build up LoL from nothing in 2009 age but now 5 years later it is the very same force that will bring it down.  I have seen many of my friends of a range of levels from Bronze to Master on both NA/EU leave when they otherwise would have stayed.  For LoL to have "staying power" it has to have core momentum that is driven by the game, and not by player imput.  Otherwise LoL will simply decay, and "die" with time.


Furthermore, least you forgot, the "word of mouth" approach only got so far.  Throughout it's history LoL has been known as "a toxic community".  And although at certain points (such as around lauch) this toxicity was tempered this was always a "turn off" for mainstream gamers.  The percentage of gamers who MOBA is still rather quite low... even when compared to other online gaming experiences such as MMORPGs.


**With funding and vision the LoL game franchise could be far greater then what it is today; ending far beyond the MOBA it is today, alas I don't yet see it happening here yet.  Indeed once again another game company, coming so close to a Grand Conquest of the Video Game Industry, only to fall at the very end:  This game has at best 1 more season before it completely collapses under it's own weight otherwise.**


**Least we not forget:  RIOT (although owned by a mega Chinese Internet company) is a "One-Game Army" and if it cannot manage it's future it will eventually go bankrupt.**

The problem with this, is that there is no position (from what I know) at Riot, that is staffed enough for this. Also, it is counter-intuitive to how League of Legends has gotten to where it is, word-of-mouth. You play League because someone told you to try it out then you tell others to play because you play.

This is the biggest "marketing" point that League has. 

Also, the constant updates, balancing changes (whether they are strictly for Competitive Play or for the average users that is moot).

I can understand that you want to see content about the game on the the site the company has for the community. I understand that, but that would require a staff to do so, right now these forums are gazed at, skimmed, and moderated. You want more than that, but that is where reporters, investigators, and fan-communities. All of which are 3rd party (like most things in sports).

You will never see a reporter directly from the NFL, posting interviews, reviewing games, or anything of the such. You have ESPN, you have Football Communities that hash all of that out.

Same with League, you have OnGamers, Surrender@20 (MOOBEAT) Thoorin, ReignofGaming, Reddit, Insight on Esports (featuring the amazing montecristo on Summoning Insight).

Pros are always doing interviews with people, Go Travis (Gafford).

tl:dr Riot encourages and even provides some of the things you want. Not likely in the quantity you want it, but if you want more, you'll have to look outside of Riot.

About the posting more, Riot just needs more community managers, right now I think they have a team of them for all leagueoflegends.com forums. Which if you look, is a lot of forums.

So who of them performed better in the Spring Split? I am not talking about the past. Piglet at his prime was better than Wildturtle by far (even though Wildturtle did very well at Season 3 worlds aswell in case you forgot) but at the moment Wildturtle performs better.

You have to watch the games. If we were talking a sheer 1 v 1. I would say Piglet performed better. The only reason Turtles stats are better Spring split was because of the team as a whole. He was less consistent than Piglet, but because of his team his stats prevailed.

So it really comes down to what way you look at the matchup. Also, you have to remember that stability of TSM that could help keep Turtle from tilting and/or the pressure off. That opposed to TL where Piglet and Fenix just came in. Both have communication barriers they are working through, then you have a community flaunting ridiculous shit like #BringKEITHback and calling Piglet shit, on no part of Piglet.

People just had an over-estimation of Piglet coming into a team, with a different language, team style, and overall professional environment as a whole. (You wouldn't believe what Korean professionals deal with and what help they get from their staff. Its crazy!)

Piglet did not perform better than Wildturtle during the Spring Split. If you think that you haven't watched his games. He did well in the playoffs but in the regular season he often underperformed. It doesn't matter who is responsible for that (language barriers, community, etc..) cause I am talking about the performance and there is no question that Wildturtle did alot better than Piglet in the Spring split.

Turtle was carried most of the season. Sacrifices that Bjerg, Lustboy, Santorin or even Dyrus had to make to keep him in the game and relevant. Team Liquid didn't have that cohesion/synergy to provide the same. Which we saw much better after the two weeks he sat out and Keith came back. You could tell they we all playing with more confidence and that they were just more comfortable with each other.

I watch a lot of competitive league and I can tell you in all honesty, no fanboy glasses or beer goggles, that Piglet; throughout the whole split, played better. I say once again for the whole Spring Split, it is what you said (which includes the playoffs) that he played better than Wildturtle. It just took him and the entire TL roster time to get comfortable.
Well that is your opinion then, I don't share it but I can respect it.
